title: Hosea Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 2.

questions.question: What names does Hosea 2:1 tell you to say to your brethren and sisters?
questions.correctAnswer: Ammi and Ruhamah
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:1 specifically instructs to say 'Ammi' to brethren and 'Ruhamah' to sisters.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:2, what is the relationship status described between God and the woman?
options: She is not my wife, neither am I her husband
questions.correctAnswer: She is not my wife, neither am I her husband
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:2 states that she is not the wife of God, nor is He her husband.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hosea 2:3: 'Lest I strip her naked, and set her as in the day that she was _______, and make her as a wilderness.'
questions.correctAnswer: born
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:3 says 'set her as in the day that she was born,' indicating a complete stripping down to innocence or vulnerability.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:4, why will God not have mercy upon her children?
questions.correctAnswer: They are children of whoredoms
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:4 clearly states that mercy will not be shown because the children are described as children of whoredoms.

questions.question: What did the mother say that caused shame according to Hosea 2:5?
options: I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water
I will serve the LORD only
I will build altars to God
I will seek peace and justice
questions.correctAnswer: I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:5 quotes the mother saying she will follow her lovers who provide for her needs.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 2:6 says God will hedge up her way with thorns and make a wall so she cannot find her paths.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:6 describes God blocking her way with thorns and walls to prevent her paths.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:7, what will the woman decide to do after she cannot find her lovers?
questions.correctAnswer: Return to her first husband
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:7 says she will decide to return to her first husband because that time was better for her.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:8, what did the woman fail to recognize she received from God?
options: Corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:8 lists these gifts given by God that she did not acknowledge.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 2:10 says God will reveal her lewdness in the sight of her lovers and none shall deliver her out of His hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:10 confirms God will expose her lewdness and none will rescue her.

questions.question: What will God cause to cease according to Hosea 2:11?
options: All her mirth, feast days, new moons, sabbaths, and solemn feasts
questions.correctAnswer: All her mirth, feast days, new moons, sabbaths, and solemn feasts
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:11 specifies God will stop all her celebrations and religious festivals.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:12, what will happen to her vines and fig trees?
options: They will be destroyed and become a forest for beasts
They will flourish and produce fruit
They will be harvested for worship
They will be given as gifts
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and become a forest for beasts
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:12 says God will destroy her vines and fig trees and make them a forest eaten by beasts.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 2:14 states that God will allure her and bring her into the wilderness to speak comfortably to her.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:14 describes God's plan to allure and comfort her in the wilderness.

questions.question: What will God give her from the wilderness, according to Hosea 2:15?
options: Her vineyards and the valley of Achor
questions.correctAnswer: Her vineyards and the valley of Achor
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:15 promises restoration of vineyards and the valley of Achor as a door of hope.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:16, what name will she call the LORD instead of Baali?
questions.correctAnswer: Ishi
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:16 says she will call the LORD 'Ishi' rather than 'Baali'.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Hosea 2:23: 'I will say to them which were not my people, _______; and they shall say, Thou art my God.'
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art my people
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:23 states God will declare 'Thou art my people' to those who were not His people.

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer struggles with temptation to follow worldly desires instead of God. Based on Hosea 2, what biblical truth would you share about faithfulness and repentance?
options: God calls us to turn away from adulteries and return to Him, promising restoration and hope.
God ignores our unfaithfulness if we continue in it.
Worldly desires are more fulfilling than God's blessings.
Repentance is not necessary if we feel guilty.
questions.correctAnswer: God calls us to turn away from adulteries and return to Him, promising restoration and hope.
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:2-7 teaches that turning away from unfaithfulness and returning to God leads to restoration. Verses 14-15 reveal God's promise to allure and comfort us, giving hope and renewal.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2 illustrate God's discipline when His people turn from Him?
options: God will hedge up their way with thorns and remove His blessings until they repent.
God rewards their disobedience with more blessings.
God ignores their sin and lets them continue without consequence.
God instantly destroys them without warning.
questions.correctAnswer: God will hedge up their way with thorns and remove His blessings until they repent.
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 9 show God removing blessings and obstructing the path of those who pursue idols, disciplining them to bring them back to Himself.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because of past failures. Based on Hosea 2, what encouraging truth about God's mercy can you share?
options: God promises to have mercy and restore those who were not shown mercy before.
God will never forgive past failures.
Only perfect people receive God's mercy.
God's mercy is limited to certain times.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to have mercy and restore those who were not shown mercy before.
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:23 declares God's mercy on those who had not obtained mercy and His invitation to become His people, emphasizing His faithfulness and forgiveness.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2 teach about the importance of knowing God in a personal relationship?
options: God desires to be called 'Ishi' and for us to know Him intimately, not as a mere idol.
Knowing God is unnecessary if we follow rituals.
God wants to be feared but not known personally.
Intimacy with God is reserved for special people only.
questions.correctAnswer: God desires to be called 'Ishi' and for us to know Him intimately, not as a mere idol.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 reveals God’s desire for a close, personal relationship, replacing the names of false gods with intimacy and knowledge of the LORD.

questions.question: What does Hosea 2 teach about God's response to unfaithfulness in marriage and spiritual life?
options: God disciplines unfaithfulness but ultimately desires reconciliation and restoration.
God immediately cuts off all relationship without hope of return.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines unfaithfulness but ultimately desires reconciliation and restoration.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 describe God's discipline, while verses 14-20 express His intent to restore and betroth His people in righteousness, lovingkindness, and faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement over lost blessings. What biblical principle from Hosea 2 can help them understand God's discipline?
options: God may remove blessings to awaken us to true dependence and lead us back to Him.
Blessings are always permanent regardless of our faithfulness.
God punishes us endlessly without hope of restoration.
We should seek blessings from idols instead.
questions.correctAnswer: God may remove blessings to awaken us to true dependence and lead us back to Him.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 show God taking away provisions given to idols, signaling that blessings are given by God and can be removed to prompt repentance and return.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2 teach about the role of spiritual discipline during trials?
options: God may cause joy and feasts to cease to bring awareness and repentance.
Trials are random and unrelated to spiritual life.
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary in trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God may cause joy and feasts to cease to bring awareness and repentance.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 explains the removal of mirth, feast days, and sabbaths as part of God's disciplinary process to lead His people back to Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 2, God promises to break the bow, sword, and battle to bring peace and safety to His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:18 states God will break weapons and make His people lie down safely, illustrating His desire for peace and security.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 2 teaches that God will forget those who forget Him and not restore them.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Despite Israel's forgetfulness (verse 13), God promises restoration and mercy (verses 14-20), showing His steadfast love and willingness to forgive.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Hosea 2, God says, 'I will betroth thee unto me in _______, and in judgment, and in lovingkindness, and in mercies.'
questions.correctAnswer: righteousness
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:19 specifically mentions righteousness as a key quality in God's betrothal to His people, along with judgment, lovingkindness, and mercies.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2 instruct believers about the consequences of turning to false sources for provision?
options: Turning to false lovers leads to loss of God's provision and spiritual barrenness.
False sources provide lasting true blessings.
God supports idolatry if it meets physical needs.
Provision from idols is blessed by God.
questions.correctAnswer: Turning to false lovers leads to loss of God's provision and spiritual barrenness.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-9 explain that Israel sought provision from idols but God will remove these blessings and cause spiritual dryness like a wilderness.

questions.question: What practical lesson about parenting and family life can we learn from Hosea 2 regarding the consequences of unfaithfulness?
options: Children suffer consequences from parental unfaithfulness, emphasizing the need for godly parenting.
Children are unaffected by parents' spiritual choices.
Parenting does not relate to spiritual obedience.
Unfaithfulness has no impact on family life.
questions.correctAnswer: Children suffer consequences from parental unfaithfulness, emphasizing the need for godly parenting.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states God will not have mercy on children of whoredoms, highlighting the impact of parents' faithfulness on family.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2, what biblical principle about stewardship and gratitude can believers learn?
options: Recognize God as the source of all blessings and avoid attributing them to idols.
Blessings come from human effort alone.
We should give credit to worldly sources for our success.
Gratitude is not important in stewardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God as the source of all blessings and avoid attributing them to idols.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains that God gave corn, wine, and oil, but Israel wrongly attributed these to Baal, teaching us to give God proper credit.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2 encourage believers in the church to serve others despite challenges?
options: God promises to restore and bring hope, encouraging perseverance in service.
Serving others is futile during trials.
God abandons the faithful in difficulties.
Challenges mean we should stop serving.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to restore and bring hope, encouraging perseverance in service.
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 describe God’s comforting presence and restoration, which motivates believers to continue serving and trusting Him.

questions.question: What does Hosea 2 teach about the importance of humility and contentment in our relationship with God?
options: Returning to God humbly leads to restoration and joyful singing like in youth.
Humility is not needed in spiritual life.
questions.correctAnswer: Returning to God humbly leads to restoration and joyful singing like in youth.
questions.explanation: Verse 15 shows that after God’s restoration, the people will sing as in the days of their youth, symbolizing joy from humble return.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:1, what names are the brethren and sisters instructed to call each other, and what is the significance of these names in the prophetic context?
questions.correctAnswer: Ammi and Ruhamah
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:1 commands to call the brethren 'Ammi' (meaning 'my people') and the sisters 'Ruhamah' (meaning 'having obtained mercy'), signifying God's restored relationship with Israel despite previous judgment.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'whoredoms' and 'adulteries' in Hosea 2:2 function as a metaphor in the context of Israel's relationship with God?
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The terms 'whoredoms' and 'adulteries' in Hosea 2:2 metaphorically describe Israel's idolatry and breach of covenant, reflecting the prophetic use of marital unfaithfulness to symbolize spiritual infidelity.

questions.question: What is the consequence described in Hosea 2:3 if Israel does not put away her adulteries, and how does this reflect ancient Near Eastern covenant curses?
options: She will be made like a wilderness and slay her with thirst
She will be exiled to Babylon
She will be blessed with abundance
She will be crowned queen of nations
questions.correctAnswer: She will be made like a wilderness and slay her with thirst
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:3 warns that Israel will be stripped naked and become like a barren wilderness, symbolizing divine judgment consistent with covenant curses found in Deuteronomy for unfaithfulness.

questions.question: Which verse in Hosea 2 emphasizes that God will no longer have mercy on the children because they are 'children of whoredoms,' and what does this reveal about the communal nature of sin in Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Hosea 2:4
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:4 states that God will not have mercy on the children because they are 'children of whoredoms,' illustrating the collective responsibility and inherited consequences of Israel’s unfaithfulness.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:5, Israel says, 'I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water.' How does this statement reflect the socio-economic realities of ancient Israel and its idolatry?
options: Seeking political and economic alliances with foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking political and economic alliances with foreign gods
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:5 shows Israel’s reliance on pagan deities for material provision, indicating the political and economic motivations behind idolatry common in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily employed in Hosea 2:6-7 where God hedges up her way with thorns and she seeks her lovers but cannot find them?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The passage uses irony: Israel chases after her lovers expecting satisfaction, but is frustrated and blocked, highlighting the futility of idolatry as expressed in Hosea 2:6-7.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:8, what did Israel not realize about God’s blessings, and how does this relate to the concept of idolatry as theft or misappropriation?
options: God gave her corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold which were offered to Baal
questions.correctAnswer: God gave her corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold which were offered to Baal
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:8 reveals that God provided material blessings that Israel misattributed to Baal, illustrating how idolatry is a misappropriation of God’s gifts.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 2:11 states that God will cause all Israel’s mirth and feasts to cease, including new moons and sabbaths, as a judgment for idolatry.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:11 explicitly says God will cause Israel’s celebrations and religious feasts to cease, indicating judgment on their idolatrous practices.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:12, what happens to the vines and fig trees that Israel claimed as rewards from her lovers, and what is the significance of this imagery in the ancient Near Eastern agricultural context?
options: They are destroyed and become a forest eaten by beasts
They are taken to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: They are destroyed and become a forest eaten by beasts
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:12 describes the destruction of Israel’s agricultural produce, a metaphor for lost blessings and divine judgment, reflecting the importance of vineyards and fig trees in Near Eastern livelihood.

questions.question: What new relationship terminology does God declare in Hosea 2:16 that Israel will use for Him, and how does this reflect a shift in covenant intimacy?
questions.correctAnswer: Ishi instead of Baali
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:16 shows God will be called 'Ishi' ('my husband') rather than 'Baali' ('my master'), signifying a personal, intimate covenant relationship replacing idolatrous titles.

questions.question: How does Hosea 2:18 describe the peace that will be established in the future covenant, and which other biblical passages echo this imagery of harmony among creatures?
options: Breaking the bow and sword so creatures lie down safely
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking the bow and sword so creatures lie down safely
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:18 depicts a covenant with the beasts and birds, breaking weapons to ensure peace, echoing Isaiah 11:6-9’s vision of harmony among creatures.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:19-20, God promises to betroth Israel to Himself in righteousness, judgment, lovingkindness, mercies, and faithfulness. How does this language connect to the broader biblical theme of covenant?
options: It emphasizes a renewed, faithful covenant relationship
It introduces a new pagan ritual
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes a renewed, faithful covenant relationship
questions.explanation: The betrothal language in Hosea 2:19-20 symbolizes a restored covenant marked by divine attributes, reflecting the biblical theme of God’s committed relationship with His people.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'valley of Achor' mentioned in Hosea 2:15 as 'a door of hope,' considering its historical context in Israel’s history?
options: It was the site of Achan’s sin, now repurposed for hope
It was a place of victory against enemies
It was the birthplace of Hosea
It was the location of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It was the site of Achan’s sin, now repurposed for hope
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:15 uses the valley of Achor, known from Joshua 7 as a place of judgment for sin, as a symbol of transformation into hope, illustrating God’s redemptive purposes.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:23, what does God declare about those who were 'not my people,' and how does this reflect the prophetic theme of restoration and inclusion?
options: They will be called my people and acknowledge God as their God
questions.correctAnswer: They will be called my people and acknowledge God as their God
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:23 prophesies a reversal where those previously excluded are embraced as God's people, highlighting the inclusive restoration theme in prophetic literature.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:14, God says He will 'allure her, and bring her into the wilderness, and speak comfortably unto her.' How does this foreshadow New Testament themes of spiritual restoration?
options: It prefigures Christ’s ministry of redemption and intimate restoration
It describes a physical wilderness journey only
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Christ’s ministry of redemption and intimate restoration
questions.explanation: The tender language in Hosea 2:14 anticipates God’s redemptive approach, paralleling New Testament themes of Christ restoring sinners through love and comfort.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:1, what names are the brethren and sisters called to be addressed as?
questions.correctAnswer: Ammi and Ruhamah
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:1 explicitly instructs to call brethren 'Ammi' meaning 'my people' and sisters 'Ruhamah' meaning 'having obtained mercy'. These names reflect God's covenant relationship with His people. Similarly, in Isaiah 43:1, God calls Israel 'my people', and in Lamentations 3:22-23, God's mercy is emphasized as steadfast.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:2, why does God say He is not the husband of Israel anymore?
options: Because she is unfaithful and must put away her whoredoms
Because He has given her a new covenant
Because she has returned to Egypt
Because He has chosen another people
questions.correctAnswer: Because she is unfaithful and must put away her whoredoms
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:2 portrays Israel's spiritual adultery, causing God to declare He is no longer her husband unless she removes her whoredoms. This metaphor of covenant unfaithfulness is echoed in Jeremiah 3:6-10 and Ezekiel 16:15, emphasizing God's righteous judgment against idolatry.

questions.question: What consequence does God describe in Hosea 2:3 if the wife does not remove her adulteries?
options: He will strip her naked and make her like a wilderness
He will give her a new husband
He will send a prophet to warn her
questions.correctAnswer: He will strip her naked and make her like a wilderness
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:3 warns of severe judgment, symbolized by nakedness and desolation. This reflects God's holiness and justice, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15-24 and Isaiah 5:1-7, where covenant disobedience brings desolation.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:5, what did Israel say that indicates her idolatrous reliance?
options: "I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water"
"The LORD is my shepherd, I shall not want"
"We will serve the LORD our God"
"Blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD"
questions.correctAnswer: "I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water"
questions.explanation: Verse 5 reveals Israel’s idolatry, trusting false gods for sustenance, violating covenant reliance on Yahweh. This theme appears in Jeremiah 2:12-13 and Isaiah 44:9-20, exposing futile idolatry versus true provision from God.

questions.question: What does God say He will do to Israel's paths in Hosea 2:6?
options: Hedge them up with thorns and make a wall
Open them wide and bless her travels
Guide her paths with His light
questions.correctAnswer: Hedge them up with thorns and make a wall
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:6 depicts God's judgment by obstructing Israel's idolatrous pursuits. This imagery aligns with Deuteronomy 32:13 and Psalm 1:6, showing God’s control over the destiny of His people based on obedience or disobedience.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:7, why will Israel say she will return to her first husband?
options: Because it was better with Him than with her lovers
Because her lovers have forgiven her
questions.correctAnswer: Because it was better with Him than with her lovers
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows Israel's repentance, realizing the futility of idolatry and longing for restoration with God. This theme echoes the prodigal son in Luke 15:17-20 and Jeremiah 3:1, highlighting God's patience and mercy.

questions.question: What blessings did Israel fail to acknowledge as coming from God, according to Hosea 2:8?
options: Corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Corn, wine, oil, silver, and gold
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:8 highlights Israel's ingratitude for God’s provision, attributing blessings to Baal. This rejection of God's gifts aligns with Deuteronomy 8:10-18 and James 1:17, emphasizing God as the source of all blessings.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:11, what will God cause to cease as part of His judgment?
options: Her mirth, feast days, new moons, sabbaths, and solemn feasts
questions.correctAnswer: Her mirth, feast days, new moons, sabbaths, and solemn feasts
questions.explanation: Verse 11 pronounces judgment on Israel’s religious festivals, which had become corrupted by idolatry. This is consistent with Amos 5:21-24 and Isaiah 1:13-14, where external worship without righteousness is rejected by God.

questions.question: What does Hosea 2:13 say Israel did that caused God to visit judgment upon her?
options: Burned incense to Baalim, decked herself with jewels, and forgot the LORD
Feasted on the LORD’s appointed times
questions.correctAnswer: Burned incense to Baalim, decked herself with jewels, and forgot the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 13 condemns Israel’s idolatry and spiritual adultery by worshiping Baal and forgetting God. This is paralleled in 1 Kings 18:21 and Jeremiah 7:9-11, underscoring the breach of covenant loyalty.

questions.question: How does God describe His future action toward Israel in Hosea 2:14?
options: He will allure her, bring her into the wilderness, and speak comfortably to her
He will abandon her to her lovers
He will send a prophet to rebuke her
questions.correctAnswer: He will allure her, bring her into the wilderness, and speak comfortably to her
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:14 reveals God's redemptive plan, showing His patience and desire for restoration. This is reminiscent of Exodus 3:12 and Isaiah 40:1-2, where God comforts His people and calls them back.

questions.question: What does the 'valley of Achor' symbolize in Hosea 2:15?
questions.correctAnswer: A door of hope
questions.explanation: Verse 15 uses 'valley of Achor' as a metaphor for turning judgment into hope, showing God's transformative mercy. This concept parallels Joshua 7:24-26 and Romans 5:5, where hope springs from God's love.

questions.question: What new name will Israel call the LORD in Hosea 2:16, indicating a restored relationship?
questions.correctAnswer: Ishi (My Husband)
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:16 shows a covenantal renewal where Israel calls God 'Ishi', signifying intimacy and faithfulness. This contrasts with 'Baal' and aligns with Isaiah 54:5 and Revelation 21:2-3, where God is described as a husband to His people.

questions.question: According to Hosea 2:18, what will God break to establish peace on the earth?
options: The bow, the sword, and the battle
questions.correctAnswer: The bow, the sword, and the battle
questions.explanation: Verse 18 prophesies eschatological peace where God ends warfare, echoing Isaiah 2:4 and Micah 4:3, which envision a future kingdom of peace under God's reign.

questions.question: In Hosea 2:19-20, how does God describe His covenant with Israel?
options: Betrothing Israel in righteousness, judgment, lovingkindness, mercies, and faithfulness
Breaking the covenant because of sin
Making a covenant only with the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Betrothing Israel in righteousness, judgment, lovingkindness, mercies, and faithfulness
questions.explanation: These verses use marital imagery to describe a covenant characterized by divine attributes, reflecting God's faithful and just nature. This covenant is consistent with Jeremiah 31:31-33 and 2 Corinthians 11:2, highlighting the new covenant's qualities.

questions.question: What is the significance of Israel calling God 'Thou art my God' as stated in Hosea 2:23?
options: It signifies the restoration of relationship and acceptance as God's people
It indicates a new form of idolatry
It marks the end of the covenant
It shows Israel’s rejection of God
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the restoration of relationship and acceptance as God's people
questions.explanation: Hosea 2:23 emphasizes God's mercy in restoring those not previously His people, affirming divine election and grace. This is echoed in Exodus 6:7, 1 Peter 2:9, and Romans 9:25-26, highlighting God's transformative grace.
